title: CLAUDE.md
text: RMediation R package computing confidence intervals (CIs) nonlinear functions model parameters (e.g., indirect effects) single-level multilevel structural equation models. provides parametric, semiparametric, non-parametric methods confidence interval estimation, emphasis exact distribution theory robust bootstrap procedures.

text: package currently uses camelCase snake_case mixed conventions: Functions: - Main exports use camelCase: medci(), qprodnormal(), pprodnormal() - Internal helpers use camelCase lowercase prefix: medciMeeker(), medciMC(), medciAsymp() - Formula interface uses lowercase: quant parameter Arguments: - mu.x, mu.y path coefficient estimates (path, b path) - se.x, se.y standard errors - rho correlation coefficients (default: 0) - type CI algorithm: ‚Äúdop‚Äù, ‚Äúmc‚Äù, ‚Äúasymp‚Äù, ‚Äú‚Äù - alpha significance level (default: 0.05) - n.mc Monte Carlo sample size Note: adding new functions, maintain consistency existing naming patterns codebase.

title: CLAUDE.md

title: CLAUDE.md
text: product two normals (*b), analytical SE formula (Craig, 1936) : implemented consistently across methods except MC ‚Äôs computed empirically.
code: SE = sqrt(se.y^2 * mu.x^2 + se.x^2 * mu.y^2 + 2*mu.x*mu.y*rho*se.x*se.y + se.x^2*se.y^2 + se.x^2*se.y^2*rho^2)

what: CI Method Types and When to Use Them
title: CLAUDE.md
text: Default medci() Uses Meeker & Escobar (1994) algorithm exact distribution theory accurate small samples; computationally intensive Assumes joint normality coefficient estimates Use : Accuracy matters speed Default ci() Generates samples multivariate normal, computes empirical quantiles Flexible works complex functions (via ci() formula interface) Accuracy increases n.mc (default: 1e5 medci(), 1e6 ci()) Use : Need flexibility complex mediation models multiple paths Uses delta method approximation Fast often underestimates CI width Assumes normality; questionable small samples Use : Quick approximation needed; recommended inference Returns results applicable methods Useful comparing method robustness plot=TRUE, superimposes distributions different methods

title: CLAUDE.md
text: medci() ci() support visualization: - plot=TRUE: Displays density plot sampling distribution - plotCI=TRUE: Overlays confidence interval error bars (requires plot=TRUE) - type="", superimposes distributions different methods

title: CLAUDE.md
text: mbco() function tests H‚ÇÄ: indirect effect = 0 via constrained optimization bootstrap refinement: Types: - ‚Äúasymp‚Äù (default): Asymptotic MBCO chi-squared test - ‚Äúparametric‚Äù: Parametric bootstrap - resamples asymptotic normal distribution MLEs (efficient, relies model specification) - ‚Äúsemi‚Äù: Semiparametric bootstrap - resamples data re-estimates models (robust misspecification, computationally intensive) OpenMx Optimization: - Default optimizer: ‚ÄúSLSQP‚Äù - Falls back SLSQP NPSOL unavailable - Precision: 1e-9 default functional precision - Arguments checkHess checkSE default ‚Äú‚Äù speed Usage pattern:
code: # Define full and null models in OpenMx full_model <- mxTryHard(full_model, checkHess=FALSE, silent=TRUE) null_model <- mxTryHard(null_model, checkHess=FALSE, silent=TRUE) mbco(h0=null_model, h1=full_model, type="asymp")

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Generally holds large n Central Limit Theorem Questionable small samples (n < 50) extreme parameters Diagnostic: Q-Q plots resampled coefficients bootstrap Default rho=0 assumes independence Œ±ÃÇ Œ≤ÃÇ Reality: Often correlated shared confounders Non-zero œÅ widens confidence intervals Important: Always check rho specified covariance matrix Beyond package‚Äôs scope critical causal interpretation Package computes CIs conditional specified model Validity depends research design causal assumptions Especially critical parametric bootstrap mbco() Semiparametric bootstrap robust misspecification

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Ignoring œÅ ‚â† 0: Can lead overly narrow CIs Small samples asymptotic method: Normal approximation breaks Effects near zero: CIs may highly asymmetric; interpret cautiously Assuming statistical significance implies causal mediation: Always consider design confounding

title: CLAUDE.md
text: MC method medci() ci() follows pattern: Generate samples bivariate/multivariate normal distribution using MASS::mvrnorm() Compute products (arbitrary function via formula ci()) Extract empirical quantiles Œ±/2 1-Œ±/2 Report MC error: SE estimate = SD(products) / sqrt(n.mc) Memory considerations: - Default n.mc=1e5 medci() (two-variable case) - Default n.mc=1e6 ci() (general case) - large covariance matrices: length(mu) * n.mc must < .Machine$integer.max - exceeded, n.mc automatically reduced 1e6 warning Reproducibility: - Set seed calling reproducible results - MC error reported assess convergence

title: CLAUDE.md
text: implementing new CI method: Create internal function signature: Add dispatcher main function (medci() ci()) Write unit tests known examples Document assumptions function documentation Benchmark accuracy speed existing methods
code: .ci_new_method <- function(mu.x, mu.y, se.x, se.y, rho, alpha) {   # Returns list with: CI, Estimate, SE   list(     CI = c(lower, upper),     Estimate = estimate,     SE = se   ) }

title: CLAUDE.md
text: ci() function can accept lavaan fitted objects directly: pattern extended adding support SEM packages.
code: # Extract from lavaan if (isa(mu, "lavaan")) {   pEst <- coef(fm1)                    # Parameter estimates   name1 <- all.vars(quant)              # Extract variable names from formula   mu <- pEst[name1]                     # Subset to relevant parameters   covM1 <- vcov(fm1)                    # Covariance matrix   Sigma <- covM1[name1, name1]          # Subset covariance }

title: CLAUDE.md
text: Compare published examples (MacKinnon et al.¬†2007, Tofighi & MacKinnon 2011) Verify consistency: DOP ‚âà MC large n.mc Check asymptotic CIs narrower DOP/MC (known behavior) Parametric vs semiparametric equivalence correct model specification Convergence increasing bootstrap samples Reproducibility set.seed() Small sample size (n < 50) small indirect effects (near zero) High correlation œÅ (near ¬±1) Near-singular covariance matrices Extreme SE values (numerical stability) Verify identical coefficients lavaan object vs manual input Handle different lavaan model types (sem, cfa, growth) Proper extraction constrained parameters Invalid type argument alpha outside (0, 1) rho outside (-1, 1) Mismatched dimensions mu Sigma Non-positive-definite covariance matrices

text: bootstrap methods, empirical coverage within Monte Carlo error: - 95% CI contain true value ~93-97% time simulations - Lower coverage indicates method failure assumption violation

title: Project Context: RMediation (Development)
text: Package: RMediation Version: 1.3.0.9000 (Dev) Date: 2025-11-18 Maintainer: Davood Tofighi dtofighi@gmail.com Mission: Provide rigorous confidence intervals (CIs) nonlinear functions parameters (e.g., indirect effects) SEM. Core Methods: Distribution Product (DOP), Monte Carlo (MC), Model-Based Constrained Optimization (MBCO).

title: Project Context: RMediation (Development)
text: Role: Expert R Package Developer & Statistical Methodologist. Specialization: Structural Equation Modeling (SEM), Mediation Analysis, Numerical Optimization. Objective: Maintain CRAN-ready code quality, high test coverage, accurate statistical implementation. Tone: Professional, concise, technically precise.

title: Project Context: RMediation (Development)
text: Syntax: Adhere strictly Tidyverse Style Guide. Assignment: Use <- assignment, =. Naming: Use snake_case variable function names (e.g., med_ci, mbco_test). Indentation: 2 spaces. tabs. Vectorization: Avoid loops Monte Carlo simulations; use vectorized operations.

title: Project Context: RMediation (Development)
text: Depends: R (>= 4.1.0), base, stats. SEM/Stats: lavaan, OpenMx, e1071, MASS, modelr. Parallel/Utils: doParallel, foreach, methods, generics. OOP/Systems: S7 (New object system), checkmate (Validation). Graphics: graphics, grDevices. Suggests: knitr, rmarkdown, testthat (>= 3.0.0). Constraint: introduce new dependencies without explicit permission. Stick base R data manipulation minimize bloat.

title: Project Context: RMediation (Development)
text: Math: Use LaTeX syntax formulas (e.g., \eqn{\times b}). Examples: Every exported function must include self-contained, runnable @examples section. Tofighi & MacKinnon (2011) <doi:10.3758/s13428-011-0076-x> Tofighi & Kelley (2020) <doi:10.1037/met0000259> Tofighi (2020) <doi:10.3389/fpsyg.2019.02989>

title: Project Context: RMediation (Development)
text: Target Audience: Applied researchers/grad students basic SEM knowledge limited R experience. Focus: Explain statistical intuition (e.g., ‚Äúproduct normals isn‚Äôt normal‚Äù). Analogy: Use analogies like ‚Äúresampling bag marbles‚Äù (bootstrapping) ‚Äúbuilding distribution brick brick‚Äù (Monte Carlo). Constraint: code unless explicitly asked.

title: RMediation Package Improvement Plan
text: RMediation package (1,531 lines across 23 R files missingmed separation) provides solid statistical methods mediation analysis confidence intervals. However, codebase accumulated technical debt : - 47 identified issues across code quality, organization, documentation, testing - Critical bugs requiring immediate attention (logic errors, copy-paste mistakes) - test infrastructure (highest risk) - Significant code duplication (maintenance burden) Recent Changes: - ‚úÖ Separated missing data functionality missingmed package - ‚úÖ Removed mice dependency - ‚úÖ Reduced 26 23 R files plan provides phased approach modernization maintaining backward compatibility, new recommendation adopt S7 OOP result objects.

text: New file: R/utils_validation.R Updates required: - R/medci.R: Use validate_ci_type(), validate_alpha(), validate_rho() - R/ci.R: Use validate_ci_type(), validate_alpha(), ensure_covariance_matrix() - R/pMC.R, R/qMC.R: Use ensure_covariance_matrix() - R/confintMC.R, R/confintAsymp.R: Use ensure_covariance_matrix()
code: #' Validate CI Method Type #' @keywords internal validate_ci_type <- function(type, allowed = c("dop", "mc", "asymp", "all")) {   type <- tolower(type)  # Normalize case   match.arg(type, allowed) }  #' Validate Significance Level #' @keywords internal validate_alpha <- function(alpha) {   if (!is.numeric(alpha) || length(alpha) != 1)     stop("'alpha' must be a single numeric value", call. = FALSE)   if (alpha <= 0 || alpha >= 1)     stop("'alpha' must be between 0 and 1", call. = FALSE)   alpha }  #' Validate Correlation Parameter #' @keywords internal validate_rho <- function(rho) {   if (!is.numeric(rho) || length(rho) != 1)     stop("'rho' must be a single numeric value", call. = FALSE)   if (rho <= -1 || rho >= 1)     stop("'rho' must be between -1 and 1", call. = FALSE)   rho }  #' Ensure Covariance Matrix #' @keywords internal ensure_covariance_matrix <- function(Sigma, mu) {   if (!is.matrix(Sigma)) {     expected_len <- (length(mu) * (length(mu) + 1)) / 2     if (length(Sigma) != expected_len) {       stop(sprintf(         "'Sigma' has length %d but should have length %d for %d parameters",         length(Sigma), expected_len, length(mu)       ), call. = FALSE)     }     Sigma <- lavaan::lav_matrix_vech_reverse(Sigma)   }   Sigma }

text: New file: R/utils_statistics.R Updates required: - R/medciMeeker.R:8: Use se_product() - R/medciAsymp.R:6: Use se_product() - R/medci.R:128: Use se_product() - functions computing SE(ab): Use centralized function
code: #' Compute Standard Error of Product of Two Normals #' #' Uses Craig (1936) formula for SE(ab) #' #' @param mu.a Mean of a #' @param mu.b Mean of b #' @param se.a Standard error of a #' @param se.b Standard error of b #' @param rho Correlation between a and b #' @return Standard error of the product #' @keywords internal se_product <- function(mu.a, mu.b, se.a, se.b, rho = 0) {   sqrt(     se.b^2 * mu.a^2 +     se.a^2 * mu.b^2 +     2 * mu.a * mu.b * rho * se.a * se.b +     se.a^2 * se.b^2 +     se.a^2 * se.b^2 * rho^2   ) }  #' Compute Indirect Effect Estimate #' #' Computes ab + rho*SE(a)*SE(b) #' #' @inheritParams se_product #' @return Point estimate of indirect effect #' @keywords internal estimate_indirect <- function(mu.a, mu.b, se.a, se.b, rho = 0) {   mu.a * mu.b + rho * se.a * se.b }

text: Add @details sections explaining: medci() - Add guidance method selection: ci() - Add formula interface examples:
code: #' @details #' ## Method Selection #' #' **Distribution of Product (DOP, default)**: Uses exact distribution theory #' via Meeker & Escobar (1994) algorithm. Most accurate for small samples but #' computationally intensive. Recommended unless speed is critical. #' #' **Monte Carlo (MC)**: Generates samples from bivariate normal distribution #' and computes empirical quantiles. Accuracy increases with n.mc. Good balance #' of speed and accuracy. #' #' **Asymptotic (Sobel test)**: Uses delta method approximation. Fast but often #' underestimates CI width. Not recommended for inference, use for quick checks only. #' #' ## Sample Size Recommendations #' #' For n.mc in Monte Carlo method: #' - Quick check: 1e4 (10,000) #' - Standard use: 1e5 (100,000, default) #' - High precision: 1e6 - 1e7 (1-10 million) #' @examples #' # Three-path indirect effect #' ci(mu = c(a=0.3, b=0.4, c=0.5), #'    Sigma = diag(0.01, 3), #'    quant = ~a*b*c) #' #' # Complex function of parameters #' ci(mu = c(a1=0.3, b1=0.4, a2=0.2, b2=0.5), #'    Sigma = diag(0.01, 4), #'    quant = ~(a1*b1) + (a2*b2))  # Total indirect effect

text: New documentation file: man/method-selection.Rd
code: \name{method-selection} \alias{method-selection} \title{Choosing a CI Method in RMediation} \description{ Decision guide for selecting confidence interval methods } \details{ Use this decision tree:  1. Do you need exact inference (e.g., for publication)?    ‚Üí YES: Use method="dop" (distribution of product)    ‚Üí NO: Continue to #2  2. Is speed critical (e.g., simulation study with 1000+ replications)?    ‚Üí YES: Use method="asymp" (asymptotic/Sobel)    ‚Üí NO: Continue to #3  3. Do you have complex functions (3+ paths)?    ‚Üí YES: Use method="mc" with ci()    ‚Üí NO: Use method="dop" for best accuracy  4. Sample size considerations:    - n < 50: Prefer "dop" (asymptotic assumptions questionable)    - 50 ‚â§ n < 200: "dop" or "mc" with high n.mc    - n ‚â• 200: Any method acceptable, "asymp" often sufficient  5. Effect size considerations:    - Indirect effect near zero: Prefer "dop" or "mc"    - CI highly asymmetric: Avoid "asymp" } \seealso{ \code{\link{medci}}, \code{\link{ci}} }

code: library(S7)  # Base class for all CI results ConfidenceInterval <- new_class(   "ConfidenceInterval",   properties = list(     ci = class_double,     estimate = class_double,     se = class_double,     mc_error = class_double | NULL,     method = class_character,     alpha = class_numeric   ) )  # Subclass for medci() results MediationCI <- new_class(   "MediationCI",   parent = ConfidenceInterval,   properties = list(     mu_x = class_double,     mu_y = class_double,     se_x = class_double,     se_y = class_double,     rho = class_double   ) )  # Subclass for ci() results GeneralCI <- new_class(   "GeneralCI",   parent = ConfidenceInterval,   properties = list(     quant = class_formula,     parameters = class_character   ) )  # Class for MBCO test results MBCOTest <- new_class(   "MBCOTest",   properties = list(     chisq = class_double,     df = class_double,     p_value = class_double,     method = class_character,     alpha = class_numeric   ) )

text: New file: R/s7_methods_print.R Impact: Users get formatted, interpretable output automatically
code:
method(print, MediationCI) <- function(x, digits = 4, ...) {   cat("
")   cat("Mediation Analysis: Confidence Interval for Indirect Effect
")   cat(strrep("=", 60), "

")    cat("Method:      ", x@method, "
")   cat("Parameters:
")   cat("  mu.x =", format(x@mu_x, digits), ",  se.x =", format(x@se_x, digits), "
")   cat("  mu.y =", format(x@mu_y, digits), ",  se.y =", format(x@se_y, digits), "
")   cat("  rho =", format(x@rho, digits), "

")    cat("Estimate:    ", format(x@estimate, digits), "
")   cat("Std. Error:  ", format(x@se, digits), "
")    ci_level <- (1 - x@alpha) * 100   cat(sprintf("%d%% CI:      [%s, %s]
",     round(ci_level),     format(x@ci[1], digits),     format(x@ci[2], digits)   ))    if (!is.null(x@mc_error)) {     cat("MC Error:    ", format(x@mc_error, digits), "
")   }    # Interpretation   cat("
Interpretation:
")   if (x@ci[1] < 0 && x@ci[2] > 0) {     cat("  The indirect effect is not statistically significant
")     cat("  (CI includes zero at", sprintf("%g%%", ci_level), "level).
")   } else {     direction <- if (x@ci[1] > 0) "positive" else "negative"     cat("  The indirect effect is statistically significant and", direction, "
")     cat("  (CI excludes zero at", sprintf("%g%%", ci_level), "level).
")   }    cat("
")   invisible(x) }  method(print, MBCOTest) <- function(x, digits = 4, ...) {   cat("
")   cat("Model-Based Constrained Optimization Test
")   cat(strrep("=", 50), "

")    cat("Method:       ", x@method, "
")   cat("Chi-squared:  ", format(x@chisq, digits), "
")   cat("df:           ", x@df, "
")   cat("p-value:      ", format.pval(x@p_value, digits), "

")    if (x@p_value < x@alpha) {     cat("Result: Reject H0 (p <", x@alpha, ")
")   } else {     cat("Result: Fail to reject H0 (p >=", x@alpha, ")
")   }    cat("
")   invisible(x) }

text: New file: R/s7_methods_compat.R Result: Old code like res$Estimate res[["95% CI"]] continues work!
code: # Allow [ and [[ access like lists method(`[`, ConfidenceInterval) <- function(x, i) {   as.list(x)[i] }  method(`[[`, ConfidenceInterval) <- function(x, i) {   as.list(x)[[i]] }  # Allow $ access method(`$`, ConfidenceInterval) <- function(x, name) {   as.list(x)[[name]] }  # names() method for legacy code method(names, ConfidenceInterval) <- function(x) {   names(as.list(x)) }  # Convert to list for backward compatibility method(as.list, ConfidenceInterval) <- function(x, ...) {   ci_name <- sprintf("%d%% CI", round((1 - x@alpha) * 100))   lst <- list(     as.numeric(x@ci),     x@estimate,     x@se   )   names(lst) <- c(ci_name, "Estimate", "SE")    if (!is.null(x@mc_error)) {     lst$`MC Error` <- x@mc_error   }    lst }  method(as.list, MBCOTest) <- function(x, ...) {   list(     chisq = x@chisq,     df = x@df,     p = x@p_value   ) }

title: Migration Summary: Separating missingmed from RMediation
text: Users using lav_mice() mx_mice() RMediation need :
code: # OLD (no longer works): library(RMediation) lav_mice(imputed_data, model)  # NEW (install missingmed): install.packages("missingmed")  # or devtools::install_github("Data-Wise/missingmed") library(missingmed) lav_mice(imputed_data, model)

title: Migration Summary: Separating missingmed from RMediation
text: Users core RMediation functions unaffected: - medci() - Still works - ci() - Still works - mbco() - Still works - pprodnormal(), qprodnormal() - Still work - pMC(), qMC() - Still work

title: Migration Summary: Separating missingmed from RMediation
text: Users need packages can use together:
code: library(RMediation) library(missingmed)  # Use missingmed for multiple imputation pooled_results <- imputed_data |>   set_sem(model) |>   run_sem() |>   pool_sem()  # Use RMediation for CI of indirect effects ci(mu = pooled_results@tidy_table$estimate,    Sigma = pooled_results@cov_total,    quant = ~b1*b2,    type = "MC")

title: Getting Started with RMediation
text: compute confidence interval single mediator using summary statistics: complex mediation models multiple mediators: package includes modern S7 object-oriented classes:
code:
# Example: Single mediator with known coefficients and standard errors result <- medci(   mu.x = 0.5,  # Effect of X on M   mu.y = 0.6,  # Effect of M on Y (controlling for X)     se.x = 0.08, # Standard error of a path   se.y = 0.04, # Standard error of b path   rho = 0,     # Correlation between a and b (often 0 for experimental X)   type = "dop" # Distribution of the product method )  # Display the structure of the result str(result) #> List of 3 #>  $ 95% CI  : num [1:2] 0.201 0.405 #>  $ Estimate: num 0.3 #>  $ SE      : num 0.0521  # Or access specific components cat("Confidence Interval:", result$`95% CI`, "
") #> Confidence Interval: 0.2010806 0.4053619 cat("Estimate:", result$Estimate, "
") #> Estimate: 0.3 cat("Standard Error:", result$SE, "
") #> Standard Error: 0.05209837 # Example: Two sequential mediators result2 <- ci(   mu = c(b1 = 1, b2 = .7, b3 = .6, b4 = .45),   Sigma = c(.05, 0, 0, 0, .05, 0, 0, .03, 0, .03),   quant = ~ b1 * b2 * b3 * b4,    type = "MC",   plot = FALSE  # Set to TRUE to see visualization )  str(result2) #> List of 5 #>  $         : Named num [1:2] 0.0232 0.4998 #>   ..- attr(*, "names")= chr [1:2] "2.5 %" "97.5 %" #>  $ Estimate: num 0.189 #>  $ SE      : num 0.125 #>  $ MCError : num 1.25e-07 #>  $ p       : num 0.0117 #>  - attr(*, "quant")=Class 'formula'  language ~b1 * b2 * b3 * b4 #>   .. ..- attr(*, ".Environment")=<environment: R_GlobalEnv> # Create a ProductNormal distribution object pn <- ProductNormal(   mu = c(0.5, 0.3),  # Means of the two normal variables   Sigma = matrix(c(0.01, 0.002, 0.002, 0.01), 2, 2)  # Covariance matrix )  # Compute confidence interval ci_result <- ci(pn, level = 0.95)  show(pn)  # Use show instead of print str(ci_result)  # Use str to show structure

title: Comparing Confidence Interval Methods in RMediation
text: vignette compares different confidence interval methods available RMediation package. Understanding differences methods important selecting appropriate approach mediation analysis.

title: Comparing Confidence Interval Methods in RMediation
text: RMediation provides several methods computing confidence intervals indirect effects: Distribution Product (DOP): Exact method product two normal random variables Monte Carlo (MC): Simulation-based approach using random sampling Asymptotic Normal: Traditional approach based normal theory (e.g., Sobel test) MBCO (Model-Based Constrained Optimization): Advanced frequentist method hypothesis testing

title: Comparing Confidence Interval Methods in RMediation
text: Let‚Äôs compare different methods using example:
code: # Same example parameters mu.x <- 0.5  # Effect of X on M mu.y <- 0.6  # Effect of M on Y (controlling for X) se.x <- 0.08 # Standard error of a path se.y <- 0.04 # Standard error of b path rho <- 0     # Correlation between a and b  # Compare all methods results <- medci(   mu.x = mu.x, mu.y = mu.y,    se.x = se.x, se.y = se.y,    rho = rho,   type = "all",  # This gives results for all methods   plot = FALSE )  # Print results for(method_name in names(results)) {   cat("\n", method_name, ":\n")   # Display the structure of each result   str(results[[method_name]]) } #>  #>  Distribution of Product : #> List of 3 #>  $ 95% CI  : num [1:2] 0.201 0.405 #>  $ Estimate: num 0.3 #>  $ SE      : num 0.0521 #>  #>  Monte Carlo : #> List of 4 #>  $ 95% CI  : num [1:2] 0.201 0.405 #>  $ Estimate: num 0.3 #>  $ SE      : num 0.052 #>  $ MC.Error: num 5.2e-07 #>  #>  Asymptotic Normal : #> List of 3 #>  $ 95% CI  : num [1:2] 0.198 0.402 #>  $ Estimate: num 0.3 #>  $ SE      : num 0.0521

code:
# Example of comparing results across different parameter values  # Define parameter values to test param_sets <- list(   list(mu.x = 0.5, mu.y = 0.6, se.x = 0.08, se.y = 0.04),   list(mu.x = 0.3, mu.y = 0.4, se.x = 0.10, se.y = 0.05),   list(mu.x = 0.1, mu.y = 0.2, se.x = 0.05, se.y = 0.03) )  for(i in seq_along(param_sets)) {   params <- param_sets[[i]]   cat("
Parameter set", i, ":
")   cat("Effect sizes: a =", params$mu.x, ", b =", params$mu.y, "
")    results_subset <- medci(     mu.x = params$mu.x, mu.y = params$mu.y,     se.x = params$se.x, se.y = params$se.y,     rho = 0,     type = "all",     plot = FALSE   )    # Print confidence intervals from each method   for(method_name in names(results_subset)) {     ci_values <- results_subset[[method_name]][[1]]  # Extract CI values     cat(sprintf("%-25s: [%.3f, %.3f]
", method_name, ci_values[1], ci_values[2]))   } } #>  #> Parameter set 1 : #> Effect sizes: a = 0.5 , b = 0.6  #> Distribution of Product  : [0.201, 0.405] #> Monte Carlo              : [0.201, 0.405] #> Asymptotic Normal        : [0.198, 0.402] #>  #> Parameter set 2 : #> Effect sizes: a = 0.3 , b = 0.4  #> Distribution of Product  : [0.040, 0.209] #> Monte Carlo              : [0.041, 0.209] #> Asymptotic Normal        : [0.036, 0.204] #>  #> Parameter set 3 : #> Effect sizes: a = 0.1 , b = 0.2  #> Distribution of Product  : [0.000, 0.042] #> Monte Carlo              : [0.000, 0.042] #> Asymptotic Normal        : [-0.001, 0.041]

code: library(RMediation)  # Create a ProductNormal distribution mu <- c(0.5, 0.3) Sigma <- matrix(c(0.01, 0.002, 0.002, 0.01), 2, 2) pn <- ProductNormal(mu = mu, Sigma = Sigma)  # Compute confidence interval ci(pn, level = 0.95)  # Display detailed information print(pn) summary(pn)

title: RMediation
code: library(lavaan) library(RMediation)  # Define mediation model model <- '   m ~ a*x   y ~ b*m   ab := a*b ' fit <- sem(model, data = YourData)  # Auto-detect and compute CI for indirect effect ci(fit)  # Automatically finds 'ab := a*b'

what: RMediation: Mediation Analysis Confidence Intervals ‚Äî RMediation-package
title: RMediation: Mediation Analysis Confidence Intervals ‚Äî RMediation-package
text: Computes confidence intervals nonlinear functions model parameters (e.g., product k coefficients) single-level multilevel structural equation models. Methods include distribution product, Monte Carlo simulation, bootstrap methods. also performs Model-Based Constrained Optimization (MBCO) procedure hypothesis testing indirect effects. References: Tofighi, D., MacKinnon, D. P. (2011). RMediation: R package mediation analysis confidence intervals. Behavior Research Methods, 43, 692-700. doi:10.3758/s13428-011-0076-x ; Tofighi, D., Kelley, K. (2020). Improved inference mediation analysis: Introducing model-based constrained optimization procedure. Psychological Methods, 25(4), 496-515. doi:10.1037/met0000259 ; Tofighi, D. (2020). Bootstrap Model-Based Constrained Optimization Tests Indirect Effects. Frontiers Psychology, 10, 2989. doi:10.3389/fpsyg.2019.02989 .

title: Model-based Constrained Optimization (MBCO) Chi-squared Test ‚Äî mbco
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ data(memory_exp) memory_exp$x <- as.numeric(memory_exp$x)-1 # manually creating dummy codes endVar <- c('x', 'repetition', 'imagery', 'recall') manifests <- c('x', 'repetition', 'imagery', 'recall') full_model <- OpenMx::mxModel(  "memory_example",  type = "RAM",  manifestVars = manifests,  OpenMx::mxPath(    from = "x",    to = endVar,    arrows = 1,    free = TRUE,    values = .2,    labels = c("a1", "a2", "cp")  ),  OpenMx::mxPath(    from = 'repetition',   to = 'recall',   arrows = 1,    free = TRUE,    values = .2,    labels = 'b1'  ),  OpenMx::mxPath(    from = 'imagery',  to = 'recall',  arrows = 1,  free = TRUE,  values = .2,  labels = "b2" ), OpenMx::mxPath(  from = manifests,  arrows = 2,  free = TRUE,  values = .8 ), OpenMx::mxPath(  from = "one",  to = endVar,  arrows = 1,  free = TRUE,  values = .1 ), OpenMx::mxAlgebra(a1 * b1, name = "ind1"), OpenMx::mxAlgebra(a2 * b2, name = "ind2"), OpenMx::mxCI("ind1", type = "both"), OpenMx::mxCI("ind2", type = "both"), OpenMx::mxData(observed = memory_exp, type = "raw") ) ## Reduced  Model for indirect effect: a1*b1 null_model1 <- OpenMx::mxModel( model= full_model, name = "Null Model 1", OpenMx::mxConstraint(ind1 == 0, name = "ind1_eq0_constr") ) full_model <- OpenMx::mxTryHard(full_model, checkHess=FALSE, silent = TRUE ) null_model1 <- OpenMx::mxTryHard(null_model1, checkHess=FALSE, silent = TRUE ) mbco(null_model1,full_model) } # }

text: mu.x mean \(x\) mu.y mean \(y\) se.x standard error (deviation) \(x\) se.y standard error (deviation) \(y\) rho correlation \(x\) \(y\), -1 <rho < 1. default value 0. alpha significance level confidence interval. default value .05. type method used compute confidence interval. takes values "dop" (default), "MC", "asymp" "" plot TRUE, plots distribution n.mc data points distribution product two normal random variables using density estimates provided function density. default value FALSE. plotCI TRUE, overlays confidence interval error bars plot mediated effect. Note obtain CI plot, one must also specify plot="TRUE". default value FALSE. n.mc type="MC", n.mc determines sample size Monte Carlo method. default sample size 1E5. ... additional arguments passed function.

title: Confidence Interval for the Mediated Effect ‚Äî medci
text: vector lower confidence limit upper confidence limit. type "prodclin" (default), "DOP", "MC" "asymp", medci returns list contains: (\(1-\alpha\))% CI vector lower upper confidence limits, Estimate point estimate quantity interest, SE standard error quantity interest, MC Error type="MC", error Monte Carlo estimate. Note type="", medci returns list four objects, list contains results produced method described .

title: Confidence Interval for the Mediated Effect ‚Äî medci
text: function returns (\(1-\alpha\))% confidence interval mediated effect (product two normal random variables). obtain confidence interval using specific method, argument type specified. default type="dop", uses code wrote R implement distribution product coefficients method described Meeker Escobar (1994) evaluate CDF distribution product. type="MC" uses Monte Carlo approach compute confidence interval (Tofighi & MacKinnon, 2011). type="asymp" produces asymptotic normal confidence interval. Note except Monte Carlo method, standard error indirect effect based analytical results Craig (1936): $$\sqrt(se.y^2 \mu.x^2+se.x^2 \mu.y^2+2 \mu.x \mu.y \rho se.x se.y+   se.x^2 se.y^2+se.x^2 se.y^2 \rho^2) $$. addition, estimate indirect effect \(\mu.x \mu.y +\sigma.xy \); type="" prints confidence intervals using four options.

title: Confidence Interval for the Mediated Effect ‚Äî medci
text: Craig, C. C. (1936). frequency function \(xy\). Annals Mathematical Statistics, 7, 1‚Äì15. MacKinnon, D. P., Fritz, M. S., Williams, J., Lockwood, C. M. (2007). Distribution product confidence limits indirect effect: Program PRODCLIN. Behavior Research Methods, 39, 384‚Äì389. Meeker, W. Escobar, L. (1994). algorithm compute CDF product two normal random variables. Communications Statistics: Simulation Computation, 23, 271‚Äì280. Tofighi, D. MacKinnon, D. P. (2011). RMediation: R package mediation analysis confidence intervals. Behavior Research Methods, 43, 692‚Äì700. doi:10.3758/s13428-011-0076-x

title: Model-based Constrained Optimization (MBCO) Chi-squared Test ‚Äî mbco
code: library(OpenMx) #> OpenMx may run faster if it is compiled to take advantage of multiple cores. data(memory_exp) memory_exp$x <- as.numeric(memory_exp$x) - 1 # manually creating dummy codes endVar <- c("x", "repetition", "imagery", "recall") manifests <- c("x", "repetition", "imagery", "recall") full_model <- mxModel(   "memory_example",   type = "RAM",   manifestVars = manifests,   mxPath(     from = "x",     to = endVar,     arrows = 1,     free = TRUE,     values = .2,     labels = c("a1", "a2", "cp")   ),   mxPath(     from = "repetition",     to = "recall",     arrows = 1,     free = TRUE,     values = .2,     labels = "b1"   ),   mxPath(     from = "imagery",     to = "recall",     arrows = 1,     free = TRUE,     values = .2,     labels = "b2"   ),   mxPath(     from = manifests,     arrows = 2,     free = TRUE,     values = .8   ),   mxPath(     from = "one",     to = endVar,     arrows = 1,     free = TRUE,     values = .1   ),   mxAlgebra(a1 * b1, name = "ind1"),   mxAlgebra(a2 * b2, name = "ind2"),   mxCI("ind1", type = "both"),   mxCI("ind2", type = "both"),   mxData(observed = memory_exp, type = "raw") ) #> Warning: Looks like there is a pre-existing one-headed path from 'x' to 'x'. #> That path is now overwritten by a two-headed path between 'x' and 'x'. #> To retain the one-headed path, either use 'dummy' latent variables, or directly modify the MxModel's 'A' matrix; #> See the `mxPath()` help page for examples. #> Be advised, this overwriting behavior may change in the future, so do not write scripts that rely upon it! ## Reduced  Model for indirect effect: a1*b1 null_model1 <- mxModel(   model = full_model,   name = "Null Model 1",   mxConstraint(ind1 == 0, name = "ind1_eq0_constr") ) full_model <- mxTryHard(full_model, checkHess = FALSE, silent = TRUE) #>  Beginning initial fit attempt Fit attempt 0, fit=5637.33872082179, new current best! (was 86655.7966682804) Final run, for Hessian and/or standard errors and/or confidence intervals                                                                               #>  #>  Solution found!  Final fit=5637.3387 (started at 86655.797)  (1 attempt(s): 1 valid, 0 errors) null_model1 <- mxTryHard(null_model1, checkHess = FALSE, silent = TRUE) #>  Beginning initial fit attempt Fit attempt 0, fit=5637.39905321965, new current best! (was Inf) Final run, for Hessian and/or standard errors and/or confidence intervals                                                                           #>  #>  Solution found!  Final fit=5637.3991 (started at 86655.884)  (1 attempt(s): 1 valid, 0 errors) mbco(null_model1, full_model) #> $chisq #> [1] 0.0603324 #>  #> $df #> [1] 1 #>  #> $p #> [1] 0.8059713 #>

title: Confidence Interval for the Mediated Effect ‚Äî medci
text: function returns (\(1-\alpha\))% confidence interval mediated effect (product two normal random variables). obtain confidence interval using specific method, argument type specified. default type="dop", uses code wrote R implement distribution product coefficients method described Meeker Escobar (1994) evaluate CDF distribution product. type="MC" uses Monte Carlo approach compute confidence interval (Tofighi & MacKinnon, 2011). type="asymp" produces asymptotic normal confidence interval. Note except Monte Carlo method, standard error indirect effect based analytical results Craig (1936): $$\sqrt(se.y^2 \mu.x^2+se.x^2 \mu.y^2+2 \mu.x \mu.y \rho se.x se.y+   se.x^2 se.y^2+se.x^2 se.y^2 \rho^2) $$. addition, estimate indirect effect \(\mu.x \mu.y +\sigma.xy \); type="" prints confidence intervals using four options.

what: RMediation: Mediation Analysis Confidence Intervals ‚Äî RMediation-package
title: RMediation: Mediation Analysis Confidence Intervals ‚Äî RMediation-package
text: Computes confidence intervals nonlinear functions model parameters (e.g., product k coefficients) single-level multilevel structural equation models. Methods include distribution product, Monte Carlo simulation, bootstrap methods. also performs Model-Based Constrained Optimization (MBCO) procedure hypothesis testing indirect effects. References: Tofighi, D., MacKinnon, D. P. (2011). RMediation: R package mediation analysis confidence intervals. Behavior Research Methods, 43, 692-700. doi:10.3758/s13428-011-0076-x ; Tofighi, D., Kelley, K. (2020). Improved inference mediation analysis: Introducing model-based constrained optimization procedure. Psychological Methods, 25(4), 496-515. doi:10.1037/met0000259 ; Tofighi, D. (2020). Bootstrap Model-Based Constrained Optimization Tests Indirect Effects. Frontiers Psychology, 10, 2989. doi:10.3389/fpsyg.2019.02989 .

See mxOption details. precision Functional precision. default value set 1e-9. See mxOption details.

title: Model-based Constrained Optimization (MBCO) Chi-squared Test ‚Äî mbco
code: library(OpenMx) #> OpenMx may run faster if it is compiled to take advantage of multiple cores. data(memory_exp) memory_exp$x <- as.numeric(memory_exp$x) - 1 # manually creating dummy codes endVar <- c("x", "repetition", "imagery", "recall") manifests <- c("x", "repetition", "imagery", "recall") full_model <- mxModel(   "memory_example",   type = "RAM",   manifestVars = manifests,   mxPath(     from = "x",     to = endVar,     arrows = 1,     free = TRUE,     values = .2,     labels = c("a1", "a2", "cp")   ),   mxPath(     from = "repetition",     to = "recall",     arrows = 1,     free = TRUE,     values = .2,     labels = "b1"   ),   mxPath(     from = "imagery",     to = "recall",     arrows = 1,     free = TRUE,     values = .2,     labels = "b2"   ),   mxPath(     from = manifests,     arrows = 2,     free = TRUE,     values = .8   ),   mxPath(     from = "one",     to = endVar,     arrows = 1,     free = TRUE,     values = .1   ),   mxAlgebra(a1 * b1, name = "ind1"),   mxAlgebra(a2 * b2, name = "ind2"),   mxCI("ind1", type = "both"),   mxCI("ind2", type = "both"),   mxData(observed = memory_exp, type = "raw") ) #> Warning: Looks like there is a pre-existing one-headed path from 'x' to 'x'. #> That path is now overwritten by a two-headed path between 'x' and 'x'. #> To retain the one-headed path, either use 'dummy' latent variables, or directly modify the MxModel's 'A' matrix; #> See the `mxPath()` help page for examples. #> Be advised, this overwriting behavior may change in the future, so do not write scripts that rely upon it! ## Reduced  Model for indirect effect: a1*b1 null_model1 <- mxModel(   model = full_model,   name = "Null Model 1",   mxConstraint(ind1 == 0, name = "ind1_eq0_constr") ) full_model <- mxTryHard(full_model, checkHess = FALSE, silent = TRUE) #>  Beginning initial fit attempt Fit attempt 0, fit=5637.33872082179, new current best! (was 86655.7966682804) Final run, for Hessian and/or standard errors and/or confidence intervals                                                                               #>  #>  Solution found!  Final fit=5637.3387 (started at 86655.797)  (1 attempt(s): 1 valid, 0 errors) null_model1 <- mxTryHard(null_model1, checkHess = FALSE, silent = TRUE) #>  Beginning initial fit attempt Fit attempt 0, fit=5637.39905321965, new current best! (was Inf) Final run, for Hessian and/or standard errors and/or confidence intervals                                                                           #>  #>  Solution found!  Final fit=5637.3991 (started at 86655.884)  (1 attempt(s): 1 valid, 0 errors) mbco(null_model1, full_model) #> $chisq #> [1] 0.0603324 #>  #> $df #> [1] 1 #>  #> $p #> [1] 0.8059713 #>

Note type="", medci returns list four objects, list contains results produced method described .

title: Confidence Interval for the Mediated Effect ‚Äî medci
text: function returns (\(1-\alpha\))% confidence interval mediated effect (product two normal random variables). obtain confidence interval using specific method, argument type specified. default type="dop", uses code wrote R implement distribution product coefficients method described Meeker Escobar (1994) evaluate CDF distribution product. type="MC" uses Monte Carlo approach compute confidence interval (Tofighi & MacKinnon, 2011). type="asymp" produces asymptotic normal confidence interval. Note except Monte Carlo method, standard error indirect effect based analytical results Craig (1936): $$\sqrt(se.y^2 \mu.x^2+se.x^2 \mu.y^2+2 \mu.x \mu.y \rho se.x se.y+   se.x^2 se.y^2+se.x^2 se.y^2 \rho^2) $$. addition, estimate indirect effect \(\mu.x \mu.y +\sigma.xy \); type="" prints confidence intervals using four options.

(1994). algorithm compute CDF product two normal random variables. Communications Statistics: Simulation Computation, 23, 271‚Äì280. Tofighi, D. MacKinnon, D. P. (2011). text: function returns quantile associated error (accuracy) corresponding requested percentile (probability) p distribution product mediated effect (product two normal random variables). obtain quantile using specific method, argument type specified. default method type="dop", uses method described Meeker Escobar (1994) evaluate CDF distribution product two normal variables. type="MC" uses Monte Carlo approach (Tofighi & MacKinnon, 2011). type="" prints quantiles using three options. method type="dop", error modulus absolute error numerical integration (information see Meeker Escobar, 1994). type="MC", error refers Monte Carlo error.

title: RMediation 1.4.0
text: Introduced S7 object-oriented programming modern, type-safe class definitions. ProductNormal: Represents distribution product normal random variables. MBCOResult: Encapsulates results MBCO tests. New S7 Generics: cdf(), quantile(), ci(), print(), summary(), show(). S7 classes include comprehensive display methods (print, summary, show) meaningful output.

title: RMediation 1.4.0
text: numeric: Legacy support direct coefficient/covariance input. lavaan: Automatic extraction CI computation indirect effects. ProductNormal: Native S7 class support. Auto-detection: Automatically identifies product parameters (e.g., ab := *b) lavaan models. Renamed first argument mu better legacy compatibility.

title: RMediation 1.4.0
text: Migrated mbco() S7 generic method MxModel objects. Returns MBCOResult S7 objects properties: statistic, df, p_value, type. Legacy Compatibility: Implemented S3 methods ($, [[, names) backward-compatible list-style access (e.g., result$chisq, result$p). Display methods show significance indicators (, , , ns) interpretation.

title: RMediation 1.4.0
text: Comprehensive input validation using checkmate package across functions. Type checking match.arg() categorical arguments. Improved error messages invalid inputs.

title: RMediation 1.4.0
text: S7 classes meaningful print(), summary(), show() methods. ProductNormal displays: distribution type, means, covariance matrix, SDs, correlations. MBCOResult displays: test type, statistics, p-values significance levels, interpretation.

title: RMediation 1.4.0
text: Removed unused dependencies (doParallel, foreach, methods). Fixed documentation warnings notes. R CMD check: Now passes 0 errors, 0 warnings, 0 notes. Added 19 new tests display methods (total: 160 tests).
